captions.text: Dear people of Team Cat Mojo.

This is a public
service announcement.

My name is squirt,
squirt bottle.
You may use me to remain stains.

You may use me to
water your garden.

What you should not
use me for, and what

has upset many of my brethren,
is to punish your animals.
Welcome to the Cat Cave.

Alright, it's time we talked
about squirt gun diplomacy.

If I can't use this, how
do I discipline my cat?

No such thing as
disciplining your cat.

I'm sorry to say folks,
they have no idea

what you're talking about when
you use this voice on them.
Squirt guns do not work.
They do not work.
Now let's use an example.

Let's say your cat
is counter surfing.

Counter surfing of course
means that they're just

walking across the
counters, and it's

something that
drives you insane.

And you would much rather
that your cats aren't counter
surfing.

If you wanted your cat
to stop counter surfing,

then every single time,
24/7, that they jump up

on the counter-- if you
wanted to be hanging out

with Mr. squirt
bottle, and you wanted

make sure that they got off
the counter, when then you've

got to camp out there,
all day, every day.

Then when you're not
around, I promise you
your cat is counter surfing.

I promise that you haven't
taught them a thing.

All they know is that
when you're around,
they shouldn't do something.

And when you're not
around, they will.

So you have succeeded
in diminishing

the bond between you
and your cat completely.

They are afraid of you, not
afraid of the experience

of getting wet when they
jump up on the counter.

So it's something that I find
really, really important,

because it follows
that line of thinking.
Can cats be disciplined?
No, of course they cannot.

What let's say
that we were using

an air-compressed canister and
an electric eye, that tool.

Put down, cat jumps up,
squirt squirt, OK, with air.
And they're gone.
What's the big difference there?

That you didn't do it,
the counter did it.
That's an effective no.

What can you do if
there's something

that you would rather
your cat not do?

Well you've got to
make it work for them.

So counter surfing-- first
of all, what does it attain?

Are you keeping
food on the counter

and then asking your cat
not to eat that food?

Is your cat a big fan of running
water out of a faucet, and yet

there is no running water
in the form of fountains
any place else?

Or is your cat thriving on
potentially negative attention?
It doesn't really matter.

If you yell at your cat
or praise your cat--
it's attention, right?

So if every time I
jump up on the counter,

I get attention,
negative or positive,

short of striking or squirting
or whatever, then I'll
probably keep doing it.

If absolutely
nothing happens when

I jump up on the counter--
no food, no reward, no lovey

dovey, no pick
you up and put you

down, no pet on the way down, no
yelling your name, no nothing.
Nothing happens.

Then why would I
continue to do it?

OK so now we get to the
second part of this.
Squirt guns are out.

So now we get to what
I call the yes no.

It doesn't matter whether
you're parenting someone
with for legs or two.

The yes no is a great
way of doing things.

Let's go back to our
counter surfer friend

who, every time you're in the
kitchen, has to be out there.
We can do something very simple.
For instance, use a placement.

The placemat has double-sided
sticky tape on it,

which is a really cool little
trick, because you can take it

off, put away somewhere, put
it back down, it's sticky.

Every time you cat jumps up on
the counter-- sticky, sticky.
Eh, I got to go.

Or you use the
compressed air canisters

with the electric eyes that
I use, like StayAway or Scat,
any of those guys.
They go.
We just established the no.
Now where's the yes?

Well the yes for a
tree-dwelling, inquisitive,

counter surfer is something
up in that kitchen that

rises to the height,
approximately, of that counter.

Now away from the
counter, so we're

not asking them to jump up on
the counter, get sticky paws,

get frustrated, go down,
and do whatever they do.

But for them to have a sill,
a stand, a tree in the kitchen

area so while you're making
dinner, they can observe.
Yeah.
I approve, right?

My name is Fluffy and
I approve this dinner.
Then we're good.

So the moral of
the story here is

that if you want your
cat to do something,
you've got to meet them halfway.

Compromise is one
of the highest forms
of love in a relationship.

This actually signifies
something completely different,
on a deeper level.

This signifies that
we believe that we

can bend our animals
to our will, right?

And if we step back from
the squirt gun for a second,

step away from
the squirt gun, we

may realize that that is not
a humane operational system.

Squirt gun diplomacy is
not actual diplomacy.

In essence, think
about the no and yes.

And once you think
about no and yes, you'll
probably get somewhere, alright?
So anyhow.
That's all I got for today.
Keep watching.

Guys, thank you so
much for subscribing.

We passed 20,000 subscribers
on the Cat Mojo channel,

and I could not be more
proud and grateful.

And grateful to the folks at the
Animalist Network, by the way,

for helping so much and
making this a reality.
So check me out here.
Anywhere you are, I am.

I don't care if it's Twitter
or Facebook or Instagram
or YouTube or Google.
Or probably in the supermarket.

We're in the same
place at the same time.

And I would love
to hear from you.
Please leave a comment.
Please keep subscribing.

Don't forget, we just had
our second Google Hangout.

We'll be having Mojo Hangouts
onward and onward every month,

so you'll find out about
that by subscribing as well.
In the meantime, be kind to all.
We all deserve a break.
Until next time.

All light, all love,
all mojo to ya, baby.

Ahh, love ya. [MUSIC]
You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm just misunderstood.
Meow.

title: The Best and Worst Ways to Train Your Cat

comments.text:
I'm scared that I'm going to have to cover my whole house in double sided 
sticky tape if this is the case. I need some tips on my cat pippin or else 
my mom might make me get rid of him. He keeps clawing, attacking and 
jumping on everything. Iv tried spraying him with a squirt bottle which now 
I know not to do, using repellent sprays, playing with him hours straight, 
but he still messes with things. Iv even tried just ignoring him because he 
likes the negative attention. He has plenty of toys to play with and a huge 
cat tree and scratching posts. Iv tried putting cat nip on all of it but he 
still scratches the furniture, climbs the curtains, and attacks my hands 
and feet until they bleed. He won't let me pet him. He just attacks. It 
doesn't seem like he is angry. He is playing but it's like he never rests 
no matter how tired he is. If anyone has any suggestions I would really 
greatly appreciate it. At this point I am really desperate. I'm also mad 
because my mom won't try and help me. I make suggestions on ways we can try 
to fix things and she won't. She just moved into this new house we are in 
and there are objects all over the counters and tables he is interested in. 
She doesn't have time or even the space to put these things away, so 
putting double sided tape down probably won't happen because she isn't 
willing to try. I wanted to try and trim his nails but she ignores that. 
She wants to get him declawed but I dont. It's wrong and wouldn't help 
anyways. At this point I'm lost on what to do. I have to keep my eye on him 
24/7. If we leave the house he has to stay in my bedroom and I'm worried 
how that is affecting him. I would like to be able to go stay at my dads 
some weekends but of I do that I know my mom will leave him locked in my 
room the entire weekend. I cannot take him to my dads because he hates 
indoor cats. ﻿
comments.author: chickenlady4321

comments.text:
I didn't want my cat to scoot out the door [I have a small house].  The 
following solution works in ONE attempt: I have a friend stand outside 
hiding around the corner.  I open the door when the cat is near and he gets 
the blast of water and thinks the open DOOR did it.  I promise that works. 
 Cat sees no one and learns that going thru that door is NOT what he wants 
to ever do.﻿

comments.text:
When our cat does something I don't want him to do, I calmly remove him

a tree and marvelous wall mounted plank of wood. Unfortunately, he is a 
snob and doesn't go fo treats.﻿

comments.author: DrJuice1

comments.text:
I've had a kitten who likes to hang out with me all the time, including 
when I'm eating.  He used to try to eat my food, but a light tap on the 
nose with two fingers whenever he reached for my food stopped him within a 
few days.  Now he happily sits with me while I eat without attempting to 
eat my food.  Do you think such a punishment with doing things associated 
with you eg: trying to eat off your plate, chewing on your clothes, but NOT 
scratching, or biting is a good idea?﻿
comments.author: Kitche Vadimas

comments.text: How do I stop my cat spilling his water I have tried everything?﻿
comments.author: Shana Chantelle

comments.text:
I know that I am probably not going to get an answer but I thought I would 
try anyway.

Mr Galaxy, I have two cats and they are grazing eaters so unless they eat 
all their dinner at night they don't get any more until the next night and 
that is fine for them. However next door has three dogs and three cats and 
two of the cats are fine and the one that is a pain in the butt is a male 
and I can't figure out how to stop him from coming inside and eating the 
food that I leave out for my cats. 

This cat hangs around and waits, see him all the time in our section and 
when we go out that is the prime time this cat gets into our place and eats 
the food. We have tried scaring it, shooting it with the hose (I know, 
should not have probably done that but it was a last resort sort of thing) 
and even gone so far as to put hot sauce on the food and waited but 
nothing, the last worked for a few weeks then it came back. We have talked 
to the owners but they don't care, they feed their cats nothing but dry 
food about 90% of the time and so this cat us hungry and goes looking for 
food elsewhere. 

What is the reason they don't listen? Well, get this? In not so many words 
but the intent was there, the owners are on a health kick so whilst the 
don't want to get fat they don't want their cats to get fat either (but 
apparently kidney problems are si much better instead) so as the neighbors 
we are stuck with a cat who comes inside and eats our cats food.

Is there anything I can do to stop this? I don't want to put my cats food 
away every time we go out or whatever just because the owners next door 
don't want to feed their cats more the just dry food. ﻿
comments.author: alicia Martin

comments.text:
Ok so I have a question. Hopefully I can get some help. What if you are 
eating and the cat jumps up on the table. I know that putting it down is 
giving attention. But I'm still eating dinner. I don't exactly want my cat 
to eat my good or shed on it. But I don't want to give it attention. 
Answers?﻿
comments.author: Aaron Arvello

comments.text: +Marialla this is a very useful explanation, thanks for sharing!
comments.author: troller192

comments.text:
The difference between your example (eating dinner) and the counter-surfing 
example is that in one instance you are enforcing your own boundaries, and 
defending your right to eat unmolested, and the other one is trying to 
defend a space against intrusion whether or not you're there.  Cats 
definitely can learn that during certain times or circumstances a person 
may be unwilling to give them access.  They will incorporate that into 
their understanding of how to interact with you.  Trying to get them to 
learn that the counter (a non-person who doesn't seem particularly upset 
about being walked on, why are YOU making such a big deal?) is off-limits 
is just too far of a mental leap for them to comprehend.  The beauty of the 
Scat! gun is that it DOES make the counter seem "mad" to be stepped on, 
because it sprays them.  They incorporate that knowledge into their 
"relationship" with the counter.
comments.author: Marialla

comments.text:
in this situation, put it down, but while you are doing that don't say 
anything (especially its name!!) and don't look at its eyes. try to somehow 
ignore it. if it jumps again just after you put it down, you keep ignoring 
it. put it down and now you can hiss while doing that, or do a short and 
kind of loud "shh". don't say words! it works for me.

comments.text:
I need help with my one year old kitten.. I don't understand him... He will 
only love us in the morning and he will let my boyfriend and friends pet 
him but not me.. What am I don't wrong +Jackson Galaxy please please help 
me :( ﻿
comments.author: Sweetie Pea

comments.text:
I know I am not Jackson, but IMO from having cats... They have very strong 
personalities. Not all cats want to be petted and cuddled all the time. My 
tortoise back is quite bitchy & standoffish most of the time except those 
brief moments when she wants me to scratch her face & sit on my paper while 
I'm working. Hehe. I have a theory it has to do with being a tree climber 
vs bush dweller, alley cat or lap cat & how they'd act in the wild. For 
example, our tortoise back is all different colors of brown and black and 
is a tree climber, so I associate her with being an alley cat, always on 
the hunt, so she'd rather be out on her own, not being bothered, stand 
offish like a tiger, whereas our white cat would stand out more in the 
wild, be very vulnerable to predators, scared into the bushes, & so she's 
more of a lap cat who needs love & assurance & to cuddle all the time. I 
would assess your cats personality to see what type of cat she is & how 
she'd act in the wild.
Your cat could be responding to other people differently if she likes their 
smell, if they've ever given her treats she could be remembering that. She 
could be associating the sounds they make or the tone in their voice. Do 
you just start petting or do you let her smell your hand first asking in 
cat language "are you in the mood for me to touch you?" You will see her 
move her head away from you if no or she'll nudge your hand yes if so. You 
gotta ask for permission essentially first! If she's still standoffish you 
could always win her over with treats or real chicken. Haha! Mine go crazy 
over the Fancy Feast Appetizers made with real meat once in a while. Cats 
have such amazing personalities I love learning about how to communicate 
better with them! :)
comments.author: OoMASEoO

comments.text: Doing*
comments.author: Sweetie Pea

comments.text:
I have never layed and hand on my cat or squirt for that matter and when he 
does something bad ill click my fingers and he stops, just wondered why 
lol. Its like he knows what im thinking hahah. Then he'll come over and 
love me up.. i take it as a "im sorry"﻿
comments.author: kami benedetti

comments.text:
Okay Jackson i have a question. so my cat moon love to get up on the 
bathroom sank and in the  bathtub  just to drink the water out of it, i 
would really love for her to stop doing it mostly because i use chemicals 
 to clean plus the chemicals in the shampoo and conditioner that im not 
sure are okay for her to ingest. now i do have a pet fountain which she 
refuses to drink out of. should i get another or is there something else i 
can do?﻿
comments.author: shyanne swope

comments.text:
the thing with that is her litter box is in there and we have no room (yet) 
to move it any where else having 3 other litter boxes and all believe me i 
thought about it.
comments.author: shyanne swope

comments.text:
First option: always close the bathroom door and don't let her in anymore.

Second option: if you can't do that, after you take a shower/bath, briefly 
rinse the tub with water - it is very quick and effective. Now, for your 
cleaning process, just don't let her in while you're washing the bathroom, 
because all the chemicals should have gone away after you wash, scrub and 
then rinse them with water.

About your fountain: you must check if the part that she drinks the water 
from is wide enough. Cats are more likely to drink out of a "wide puddle" 
than from a "narrow pool", got it? That's why she goes to the sink and the 
tub: water puddles!
-
Also, is the fountain made of plastic? If yes, then you should just buy a 
wide and shallow water pot made of stainless steel. Plastic holds dirt and 
bacteria very easily.... And every cat hates to use nasty dirty things 
(dirty litterbox, dirty pots - or dishes, whatever they use to eat or drink 
from).
-
Note that the plastic pots must be cleaned with sponge, soap and water 
EVERY DAY. And the stainless steel pots must be washed once a week with 
soap, and everyday only with water, when you change it. Water must be 
changed daily on both kinds of pots, by the way.

Good luck.
comments.author: troller192

comments.text:
learning so much about cats. I have 6+ cats in my street, I feed them. Soon 
I'm gonna take one of them to my home :)﻿
comments.author: Jake K

comments.text: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WJcWoksdlOM﻿
comments.author: Jasko Muminhodzic

comments.text:
Compromise is key. I am very lucky with the two cats I have because they 
listen to me and if one gets on the counter and I ask him to get down he 
jumps down (I don't mind them on the counters except when I'm cooking) but 
I am redirecting them to the floor as I am asking. They also come when 
called, etc...(very dog like personalities). My home is their home and I 
thank you for your suggestions on ways to compromise to help make our home 
more cat friendly.﻿

Cat's are kool, cat really don't get it ......They just don't get it...Have

My Ragdoll cat used to jump up on a vacant chair when we ate. He didn't

comments.text:
I have an absolute skin crawling session if I see a cat walking on anything 
in the kitchen. That is totally nasty and disgusting to me. I *immediately* 
got rid of a cat that I came upon on my kitchen counter--who of course, 
NEVER did it when I wasn't around so I was flabbergasted and freaked out 
beyond comprehension when I came around the corner and saw it. He knew he 
was caught and ran. Too late. Gone he was and I've had a stress free life 
ever since! That's truly a deal breaker (besides the under the bed/couch *hide 
n swipe!* ). I hate that! Ugh!﻿

+seashellsk How nice! I trained my cat to :-D Clicker training. Very easy 
and she loves it. Yesterday i even trained her to get on a kitchenscale

comments.author: Loes Scharenborg

comments.text:
I have had both dogs and cats. I have trained my cat (Harry) just like I 
did my dogs. Harry will come when called, sit and sit up. I also will never 
allow an animal no matter what kind, to get on any counter that will have 
food on it. I made sure he has lots of places to climb and sit above the 
floor level. He just hasn't been on the counters at all. I found that cats 
aren't near the disciplining problem that dogs are. There are very few 
issues a normal healthy happy cat has except if they're sick. Most happen 
for bored cats (unrolling the TP roll) so just keep them loaded up with 
toys. They're so much easier to care for, not wanting out every 30 minutes, 
wet dog smell, can't be left overnight. They are a perfect pet! Go for it!
comments.author: seashellsk

comments.text:
+Leif Bergsköld
I got my cats after owning a labrador for over 8 years. It's gonna get you 
frustrated in the beginning, because the cat just doesn't listen. LOL Also, 
because my dog was rather big, whenever I played with my kitten they tend 
to get knock over by my hand hahaha
But yeah after 3 or 4 years of owning some cats, you start to talk to your 
dog like you're talking to your cat.
+Lissita
lolol I was like.. what's a food person? Which average person doesn't like 
food haha
comments.author: ooXChrissieXoo

comments.text:
Wow, months later I see that I put food person... I guess I was on my phone 
lol. I meant "dog", though food is always good haha.
comments.author: Lissita

comments.text:
Cats are pretty much diametrically opposite from dogs, first in body 
language, then in independence. Cats do their thing, and simply don't care 
whether you like it. Like Jackson said, when you forbid something, that 
only means they won't do it when you are around. The great thing about cats 
is that you learn a lot about yourself. You grow personally, become more 
tolerant and respectful, and also more relaxed because you have to learn to 
let go (of your decorative porcelain dolls for example...) - cats are the 
perfect preparation for having children: They are cute and manipulative, 
have a strong will of their own, and will wreak havoc.
comments.author: Trixinator

comments.text:
I've only really had dogs.. then this cat came into my life and I like how 
smart he is. It's not that bad really I think you will get used to the cat 
and learn to find interesting things about him/her. some behave like dogs!
comments.author: Stef Rose (Stef's Games)

comments.text:
I will say, cats are a lot more independent than dogs. You can own a dog 
but in a cat house the cat owns you. Lol. They are a LOT smarter though, 
like my cat can open doors & closets. It's definitely a joy having one, a 
very unique experience. I think the best part is seeing how their 
personalities develop. :)
comments.author: OoMASEoO

comments.text:
I'm totally a food person and grew up with dogs, because my family and I 
are allergic to cats... Yet, here I am living with four cats (two are my 
roommates). They're not as bad as you may think. They're easy to care for 
and even training is simple. Just like dogs are easy to train so are cats 
and they're just as loving as dogs are, not to mention entertaining as heck.
comments.author: Lissita

comments.text:
When I'm eating on the counter
And my cat jumps on to see me and sniff the food
I don't let her get close to me at all
If she does get close
I would tap her nose with two fingers
And she would back off
You usually have to do that twice because the cat might not understand what 
that means and will go quickly back to that "sniffing/getting closer" mode 
This what I do 
But I'm not saying that you should do his as well
Because all cats are different
﻿
comments.author: Stephanie Gonzalez

comments.text:
So what do you do with a 2 month old tygor kitty that likes to bite cable 
wires and plugs. Is dangerous and irritating. I try to bring him toys but 
after a while he goes back to nibling cables. Is he teething?﻿
comments.author: Maria Thornton

comments.text:
+Maria Thornton Uhmmm I used a non conventional (at all) solution to make 
him stop to do so. But yes I did waited till he reach 5 months old, I 
didn't even tried anything before that. I was afraid of him getting fried 
by chew wires with electricity on them...so I put an small cellphone 
charger tug around his neck and let him go around with it. At first he was 
happy "The wire" fallow him around and he could chew it as he wished then 
time passed and he wasn't happy any more. When he finally lay down sick and 
tired of it I took it off. Chewing wires stopped.
comments.author: tomojo333

comments.text:
+Maria Thornton They seem to love the wires because they wiggle then they 
play with them. What cat could resist such fun. I now have some electrical 
tape I use if I see any chew spots on any wires. They will out grow it.
comments.author: seashellsk

comments.text:
I think it was just that stage for the cat. One of my cat did that too... 
He chewed up everything. I have to switch to wireless mouse because he 
killed 3 already. rip my laptop charger too. But, he stopped eventually. I 
noticed that he tend to chew cable around my study or around my desk. So I 
moved my books, gave him a cat bed there, including his furry ball, 
blanket, some toys, and close my study's room so he can't stay in there 
overnight. He would try to wake you up to open the door, but you just have 
to ignore it. After that, whenever he tries to chew, I put him outside of 
the study, and doesn't let him go back till he gives up waiting at the door 
calling me.
If age doesn't solve that issue, then use cable covers, and look up how to 
bunny proofing your house, because rabbits LOVE to chew them wires up LOL
comments.author: ooXChrissieXoo

comments.text:
Try covering your thin cables with 1/4" split loom tubing. 100 ft for 
$11.00. Reinforce with vinegar.
comments.author: mel2k

comments.text: Thanks!
comments.author: Maria Thornton

comments.text:
Something to consider, not only with cats, is that when you bring an animal 
into your home, you'll both live there, so ideally you should create a home 
that is safe for both and hide or protect wires and whatever is dangerous 
for him like you do with things dangerous to yourself. Then get him some 
toy wires he can actually play with. The more entertained he is, playing, 
exploring and getting to know you, the more at home he'll feel. Don't worry 
about his baby behaviour, it's normal. In time he'll grow out of it and 
become a restless teen running around and driving you crazy ;)

My cat always comes onto my kitchen table and I obviously don't like that 
because it's unhygienic - his paws have been out and about, in his litter 
etc. Furthermore, he likes to climb in my sink which often has dirty dishes 
and eats from them. 
I've watched many of Jackson's videos and episodes from My Cat From Hell so 
I'd like to think that I know a bit about cat behaviour, but I can't 
understand what to do from stopping this from happening.
It's nothing to do with his diet - he's got his food, I know he likes his 
food and this may happen even after he's eaten.
It's nothing to do with attention either because he gets plenty, I have a 
family of four people which includes a ten-year-old so you can imagine how 
much attention he gets.
Then only thing I haven't done is tried to get something that he could sit 
on and be on the same level the table's on but I can't do that because it 
doesn't fit in my kitchen. However he does enjoy climbing on the back of 
chairs which are higher than the tables and we allow him to do that.
Up until now we've sprayed him with water but that obviously isn't working, 
I have no idea what to do. I've tried to teach him that what he does will 
have bad consequences by locking him (once, to see if it would work) in the 
bathroom but that obviously didn't work.
What do I do?﻿
comments.author: Mar tina

comments.text: I have never heard so much rubbish in my life regarding training cats.﻿
comments.author: Sinclair Macleod

comments.text:
It really depends on the cat. With my cat the spray bottle absolutely 
changed his behavior. He is playfully aggressive in the extreme (all the 
time, even when he's not being played with) and he responded to absolutely 
nothing else. He would leave you with a bloody stump before I consistently 
employed the spray bottle. Now he is still very playful but rarely gets 
carried away. I maybe have to spray him once a year now, whereas before he 
would hurt me daily. Now when he does something really bad he'll squint his 
face up because he knows he deserves a squirt, but if he does it's so cute 
that I can't squirt him. I can assure you there is no cat on earth more 
loved than mine and the spray bottle got his attention and stopped the 
behavior. ﻿

comments.author: Jake Lyles

comments.text:
Sorry but this is untrue, i have 3 cats, and each on their very first 
Christmas when they saw the tree and would attack the decorations i 
resorted to using the water squirt bottle set to a fine mist spray, when 
they attacked the tree, they got a spray and quickly learnt that anything 
bad would result in a mist spray from the squirty bottle, now 2 Christmases 
later, and they do not go near the tree to play with it, they sleep under 
it, but they know that if they do anything naughty they get a little 
squirt, and recognize the water spray as their discipline, cats are much 
smarter than this guy has given them credit for in this particular video, 
otherwise this guy does know what he is talking about and i think it's 
great he is helping to educate people to understand their cats better, but 
i do have to disagree in the case of the water squirter. works for me and 
the cats are not distressed by it at all. now i don;t even need to spray 
it, picking up the bottle is enough for them to know to stop the thing they 
are doing. sorry if others disagree, but it works for me and i love my 
three boys and as far as i can tell, they love me too :)
 ﻿

comments.author: kimkishineegirl

comments.text:
We thought about this a lot, as Mau was a very aggressive cat when we got 
her.  We decided to implement the spray bottle as positive punishment when 
she attacked us.  When we trained, we worked on basic touch interaction 
(giving positive reinforcement), and when she slapped or bit us, we would 
spray her.  After a few sessions, she began to hesitate longer and longer 
before she would substitute slapping/biting with licking.  Since we are 
always around when this happens, we are able to be consistent.  We also 
felt that it was the most aggressive/least violent counter we could give to 
her abuse.  She has learned to tolerate us, and as a result, she is now 
able to receive our affection (that she now seeks!). ☮﻿
comments.author: YouHippies

comments.text:
Water spray bottle is harmless it is one of the best way t [ train your 
kitty when they are mean toward another pet, I have a spray bottle by the 
door I am worried one of the kitties might escape it happened in the past 
lost my kitty for a week the rescue assisted me and advised me to have a 
spray bottle water to prevent it fro happening again ot work now kitties 
look at the bottle and understand they are smart and easy to teach like dog 
they are animals but they are smart.

All of my cats learn what I mean when I say 'get down'.  They know it means 
they are in a place I don't want them to be and they have to move.  Of 
course it doesn't mean they will get down, and even using a firmer voice 
doesn't always work, so instead I'll just put them on the floor, saying 
'get down', then a 'good boy/girl'.  It works well for me and my cats.﻿

comments.text:
Er... My grandma used to hit my mom's cat (now dead, at age 14, eaten by 
dogs), and I can say it was very effective. And he still let us pet him, 
play with him etc. Not saying you guys should do it but yeah, it worked a 
lot.( By the way, my grandma used to hit my mom and her sisters when they

comments.author: darkbetterlol

comments.text:
Actually to be honest guys with cats, grabbing them by the scruff and if 
necessary having to give them a little smack (obviously not to hard) is the 
only way they can stop some extreme behavior, cats know who the Alpha is, 
and sometimes you have to assert your dominance to make sure in the case of 
my three boys, that when they fight and lets be honest cats just do, you 
can step in and end it and use mild force if needed to assert your 
dominance and end a fight in seconds, i have had cats my whole life, i am 
now 30 and have 3 beautiful boys, they know who the Alpha is and know the 
pecking order of the house, they're animals and unfortunately not people, 
and you watch any David Attenborough  wildlife documentary on wild cats. 
best education you can get on how a cat needs to be treated to life happily 
and not to be confused, pecking orders are essential for a house hold with 
a cat. but you do get challenged (rarely) and just grabbing the cats scruff 
and placing your head really close to theirs (above the back of the neck) 
reasserts your dominance, sometimes you will have to hold them for 10 
minutes whilst they calm down, but as soon as they do, present them your 
hand and they will want to seek approval and a cuddle from their Alpha, 
sorry to drone on guys but this works for me and my cats are definitely 
living happy.
comments.author: Rustyboy57

comments.text:

of the most unacceptable forms of discipline, the dark side of it. It 
teaches you that you are a lesser being that is not only inadequate but 
also can only be taught by violence.

Humans have some of the most hideous tendencies, the only way to stop them

circle, one that must be stopped through love and mutual understanding.

comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
It depends on the negative behavior. Most of the time, you're right; you 
just want the cat to associate "bad" behavior with mildly unpleasant 
consequences that have nothing directly to do with you. Since I personally 
see nothing wrong with counter surfing, I'll use an *actual* bad behavior - 
wandering into areas that, if you miss the fact that they wandered in for 
any reason, could result in their deaths, or, at the very least, in them 
being abandoned and alone and scared for hours. Such as the fridge. Or the 
oven. Or the bathroom, just before you close the door and leave for 8 hours 
(it can happen. You can't be focused on them 100% of the time).

What you want to do in the case of truly bad behavior, is have them know 
that there are bad consequences, in *controlled* circumstances, when you 
*know* they are there, and you're controlling the consequences. You want 
them to understand that they absolutely *never* want to go in there, for 
any reason. In the case of the (cold) oven or the bathroom, wait for them 
to go in, then close them in and make a huge racket. In the case of the 
fridge, close them in, and wait for them to get truly scared before opening 
the fridge door again (again, controlled circumstances. This is far better 
than accidentally closing them in when you don't realize they've darted 
in). Then they will *never* go in there again. Cruel to be kind - if your 
cat is prone to going into dangerous areas, this is far safer than just 
*hoping* that you will always catch them darting or sneaking in, in time to 
save them.

I do think there's one exception to the squirt-gun/hissing rule. If they 
are coming at your face with their claws out, they need to know, 
absolutely, that this is not acceptable behavior. It works, too. Hissing at 
them, I mean. But only if they're attacking you (or a baby or a guest). 
It's bad if you use it for really minor things, like counter surfing.﻿
comments.author: Katerine459

comments.text:
+GhostOfThermopylae while I'm not American and thus the prices of course 
differ, I have to say that I tried to devise my own scratching post for the 
furry apostles of destruction and I gave up because the budget (considering 
the amount of required rope etc) was much higher than the price of a simple 
scratching mat you can fasten to a wall.
(btw I advise against scratching posts/mats containing rugs, focus on the 
ones made of rope. They're more durable and they're not sending the message

comments.author: ZutaMacka666

comments.text:
I don't quite agree with this. I respect your opinion and you are by all 
means entitled to train and do with your cats as long as its in accordance 
by law, but i feel that the concept is fueled by fear. Your basically 
causing a traumatic event (controlled as it may be) in the life of the cat 
to achieve a desired result (whether the intentions are good or not). If i 
seek a desired result, such as stopping them from entering a room such as 
as the bathroom, I rather just create a deterrent where they see the place 
as uncomfortable or dangerous as they should and give them something else 
that is healthy and positive such as a well placed cat furniture near the 
area to overlook it. I often use a home made lemon juice mix of spray to 
indicate to my cat where it is not safe to be.

On another note, i do agree that scratching posts need to be a certain 
width, height, and weight for the cat to even bother with it. Otherwise 
your better off getting one of those horizontally inclined ones cheaply 
then getting a post that's barely the cats height. Personally, the pricing 
of something simple/effective as scratching posts is disgustingly high for 
the materials used. Unless you have no desire to craft your own, all of 
these things can be found at a local handy shop such as Home Depot for you 
to create.
comments.author: GhostOfThermopylae

comments.text:
+Joana Ferro In addition to what Nienna just said... I noticed that you 
said, 'scratching pole." Those words call this to mind (picture from google 
images):

https://encrypted-tbn2.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcRJV6aO9NlUbULNM9haTSTTZLwNArrE559pw75jG3gaFJrNRV_z

If this is what you got... no offense, but no cat is going to actually 
scratch this, unless they (the cats, that is) are really tiny. Perhaps I'm 
a little biased against them due to only ever having had male tabbies 
(which grow to be roughly 20 pounds of muscle and, if they so choose, can 
knock over a small child if they butt up against them), but... yeah. My cat 
would look at something like that and think it's an odd item that's of no 
use to him whatsoever.

Cats basically have three requirements of their scratching posts. They need 
their claws to catch against the material in just the right way, that it 
sharpens them. They need to be able to stretch their muscles (one of the 
main functions of scratching - it's a bit of a workout for them). And, 
perhaps most importantly, they need the post to *not move at all*, no 
matter *how* hard they pull at it. All it takes is one wobble, and it's 
forever written off as being completely useless, and something to avoid.

There are two ways to get around this. You can buy them a really good 
scratching post, that has a wide base that they can stand on with their 
back legs and stretch, both vertically and horizontally, and is extremely 
stable, and is tall enough that they can scratch while reaching way up... 
or, if you can't afford that (since the good ones tend to be at least $90), 
there are the cheap, disposable ones that lay flat on the floor, that they 
stand on with all four legs while scratching with their front legs.

The material is important too. Clearly, your cat likes the material of the 
couch. :) You may want to try for something with a similar "catchiness" 
quality (the way it catches on their claws). If the material of the couch 
is like that of cheap business carpeting, for example, you may actually get 
away with buying some spare carpeting that's of a similar feel, and nailing 
it to a stabilized board.

What Nienna said about not forcing the cat to use the scratching post is 
correct. The right word you're looking for is, "entice," not "force." :) 
Buy a little packet of dried catnip and rub it against the scratching 
material. Or take a "stringy" toy and play with them for a while, then when 
they get really excited, draw the string up the post. If she likes the post 
after touching it, you'll know immediately, and your problems will be 
solved. Your cat *will* use a scratching post that she *likes*. She will 
not use a scratching post that she does not like. It's really that simple. 
:)

Another option: assuming your couch is a futon, try buying a cover that 
*loosely* fits around the mattress, that's a similar material to bedding 
sheets. I've never heard of a cat that scratches bedding sheets. :)
comments.author: Katerine459

comments.text:
+Joana Ferro I dont know much about cats, but what worked with me was 
putting some aluminium foil on the floor where the cat used to scratch the 
couch, he won't like the feeling of stepping on the aluminium so he won't 
go there to scratch anymore. Then put the scratching post nearby and buy a 
laser pointer and play with him while pointing the laser to the scratching 
post, he will chase the laser and notice that the scratching post feels 
good, always praise him when he uses the scratching post! And don't force 
him to use it, he will associate it with bad things.
comments.author: Nienna

comments.text:
We did get her a scratching pole, but she doesn't seem one bit interested 
in it. I've tried to force her to scratch it, but she didn't even seem to 
understand what she's supposed to be doing with that lol

Thank you both for the tips :) I'll try the spray too.
comments.author: Joana Ferro

comments.text:
+Joana Ferro Katerine makes a good point, but what I did was I made a water 
bottle, and mixed eucalyptus and lemon oils in with water, just so it was a 
strong enough scent, and sprayed the entire couch with it. My cats hated 
the smell of eucalyptus and made a point to stay away from it entirely. I 
did the same thing to my plastic Christmas tree, and wiped down any 
counters with it. My house smelled like eucalyptus and lemon (I think is a 
fantastic clean smell) but my cats would avoid the areas that smelled like 
it. 
It doesnt have to be eucalyptus. Just find some oils or a perfume or 
something that your cats will hate, (you can tell when you open the bottle 
in their general area, they will sniff it, and get all squinty eye'd, and 
then run away) And spray everything you don't want them on, and just 
respray occasionally. They will eventually associate that unpleasant smell 
with the item they are suppose to stay away from. I only had to do the 
spray three times in a corse of a month, before I could stop. They never 
scratched my couch again.
comments.author: Trisha Richardson

comments.text:
+Joana Ferro Regarding the tree... I couldn't say, sorry. :) I don't do 
Christmas trees, for precisely this reason!

Regarding the couch - she's scratching it because it's her favorite 
material in the house. It's (presumably) sturdy, and she likes the 
material. Scratching comes naturally to cats - they *need* to do it. So if 
your cat is scratching someplace you don't want, the only real solution is 
to give them better options. Invest in a really good scratching post (a 
sissal one that doesn't wobble and can take their weight), or, if you can't 
afford that, the cheap ones that lie flat on the floor, that they can stand 
on and stabilize with their back legs while they scratch with the front 
works as well. At least with my cat. But all cats are different. :)

Also, I've heard double-sided tape works well as a deterrent. :) But again, 
only if there's a viable alternative, since scratching is such a necessary 
instinctive activity.
comments.author: Katerine459

comments.text:

to scratch it, because she knows we can't get her there. What should I do?
